title: Dewa Rutji: avontuur en wijsheid in een Javaans verhaal
Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind: The Javanese Shadow-play Dewa Ruci Performed by Ki Anom Soeroto. A Study in Performance Philology (2016): contents, preface, first pp of edition
summary:
BLURB: Javanese shadow puppetry is a sophisticated dramatic form, often felt to be at the heart of Javanese culture, drawing on classic texts but with important contemporary resonance in fields like religion and politics. How to make sense of the shadow-play as a form of world-making? In Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind, Bernard Arps explores this question by considering an all-night performance of Dewa Ruci, a key play in the repertoire. Thrilling and profound, Dewa Ruci describes the mighty Bratasena’s quest for the ultimate mystical insight.
     The book presents  Dewa Ruci as rendered by the distinguished master puppeteer Ki Anom Soeroto in Amsterdam in 1987. The book’s unusual design presents the performance texts together with descriptions of the sounds and images that would remain obscure in conventional formats of presentation. Copious annotations probe beneath the surface and provide an understanding of the performance's cultural complexity. These annotations explain the meanings of puppet action, music, and shifts in language; how the puppeteer wove together into the drama the circumstances of the performance in Amsterdam, Islamic and other religious ideas, and references to contemporary Indonesian political ideology. Also revealed is the performance’s historical multilayering and the picture it paints of the Javanese past.
     Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind not only presents an unrivalled insight into the artistic depth of wayang kulit, it exemplifies a new field of study, the philology of performance.

title: SUCH A LONG JOURNEY: JOURNEY OF Doris LESSING'S HEROINES IN MARTHA QUEST AND THE SUMMER BEFORE THE DARK
summary: Doris Lessing's novels are often a tale of the protagonists who are dissatisfied with their present situation and, willingly or unwillingly, set along the road to discovery of their identity. Martha Quest and The Summer Before the Dark present before their readers two similar tales where Martha and Kate, one a young girl and the other a mother and wife of long years set out on their paths to discover who they are. A journey undertaken by the protagonist in search of her identity is a repeated motif in Lessing's canon. This journey, which can be physical, psychological and (at times) spiritual, opens up new vistas of life and provides an opportunity to her protagonists to learn more about themselves. This paper compares the journeys of two of Lessing's protagonists – Martha, the young teenage girl who leaves her home in the African farm to carve a new life for herself and Kate, a mother of four children who starts a new phase of her life when she sets on a journey that takes her to places across the world. Martha is the protagonist of an entire series of novels, The Children of Violence. The series which comprises of five novels, namely Martha Quest, A Proper Marriage, A Ripple from the Storm, Landlocked and The Four Gated City was written by Lessing in a time period spanning from 1952 to 1969. The series traces the social, spiritual and psychological growth of Martha from her early years in the colony till the time of her death. As such, the series can be read as a Bildungsroman. This genre includes the Entwiklungsroman or the novel of general growth, the Erziehungsroman or the novel of educational development and the Kuntelsrroman or the novel of artistic realisation (Brändström 4). The present paper deals with the first novel of the series Martha Quest and reads it as Martha's beginning of a long journey in the quest of her identity and as a bildungsroman, comparing it with The Summer Before the Dark (published in 1973) which follows the spiritual, psychological and physical wanderings of Kate Brown, who leaves her home somewhat grudgingly, only to realize as the novel progresses that this journey

title: Drona's betrayal and Bima's brutality: Javanaiserie in Malay culture [2018]
summary: The presence of elements explicitly identified as "Javanese" or "from Java" in traditional Malay literature and performance — settings, characters, objects, idioms, stories, texts, even entire genres like the renditions of Mahabharata story-matter — has mostly been ascribed to the putative prestige of the historical civilization of Java. Here I explore another point of view. Focusing on religiosity and ethics in a hikayat with Mahabharata stories, I propose the notion of javanaiserie, the creation of texts, performances, and other cultural artefacts designed to be considered Javanese. Javanaiserie has proven alluring in Malay contexts. Rather than as a matter of influence I suggest regarding javanaiserie as an active process of worldmaking, the creation of a reality that is culturally at once close to and distinct from an audience's everyday lifeworld, a reality that can be both elegant and evil, appealing as well as appalling.

research_interests.name: Ethnicity In Malaysia and Southeast Asia

title: Dewa Ruci and the light that is Muhammad
The benefits of purity in Amarta and Surakarta: the shadowplay of Bima Suci, 1817–1818
summary: This paper, part of a project on religious worldmaking at the court of Paku Buwana IV in Surakarta, focuses on a category of ideas about worldmaking that were ambient among the Javanese social elite. The quest, an agential, typically person-focused form of worldmaking, narrative in character, appears in variable figurations in many historical environments and different cultural domains across the globe. I describe how a literary rendition of the Javanese mythological narrative of quest known as "Bima Purified" (Bima Suci) was made into a shadowplay in 1817–1818 and how it resonated with ideas of Sufi questing in court circles.

title: Dewa Ruci door Ki Anom Suroto (Inleiding, deel v.d. tekst, vertaling) [1990] (See Arps 2016, Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind, for a full edition and translation of the same performance)
summary: For an English translation of the entire performance, see Arps, Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind (NUS Press, 2016).

title: The Road Less Travelled: Mara and Dann as a Heroine's Quest Narrative
summary: This paper proposes to re-read Doris Lessing's 1999 novel Mara and Dann: An Adventure from as a successful quest narrative that involves a heroine's journey. It makes use of Auden's famous essay " The Quest Hero " written on Tolkien's fantasy novel The Lord of the Rings to discuss how the novel successfully fits the genre of the Quest narrative and that the faults in the novel pointed out by critics are due to the limitations of the genre itself. It uses the model of a heroine's quest as discussed by Maureen Murdock in her book The Heroine's Journey: Women's Quest for Wholeness and shows how the novel follows the pattern of the journey described by Murdock closely and how it is similar and, at the same time, different from the traditional quest narrative of a hero.

title: Study Questions on Graham Greene's "Under the Garden" (1963)
“Virgil’s Aeneid and the Ambivalence of Aeneas’ Heroic Quest.” Critical Insights: The 	Hero’s Quest. Ed. Bernard Schweizer and Robert A. Segal. Ipswich: Salem House, 2012. 115 - 131.
summary:
Virgils’ Aeneid is the story of a heroic quest, but a perplexing, contradictory and unsettling one. This inverted re-telling of the Iliad and the Odyssey raises more questions than it answers.

Aeneas is a persistently unwilling hero. He would rather have fought and died in Troy than have fled the city and begun his quest as the saviour of his people. He would happily have stayed in Carthage with his beloved Dido, forsaking destined greatness. He would have avoided war with the Latins, indeed never would have come to Italy, if fate had not forced him. Aeneas is a hero in spite of himself who fulfills his heroic destiny in spite of himself.

A second problematic point is that Aeneas does not make decisions, but is commanded, guided and assisted by the gods. He leaves Carthage only after receiving a direct command from an exasperated Jove, he plots his course with the aid of soothsayers and seers, and relies on the supernatural aid of his mother Venus to counteract the supernatural malignancy of Juno. He and his people seem little more than storm-wrack drifting across the Mediterranean, powerless to meaningfully affect their course or ultimate fate. This is a heroic quest shaped by a lack of individual agency. It is not men, but the gods who decide.

This perhaps helps to excuse the horrific fulfillment of Aeneas’s quest. Arriving in Italy, all of his good intentions are frustrated. A pact between Trojan and Latin, destined brothers, is broken, and war breaks out. This is a war of terror and treachery and ambushes, of blood pointlessly and irremediably spilled over issues that are ultimately beyond human control. It is a war narrated in the heroic style of the Illiad but fought by mere humans, weak and vacillating. Aeneas claims to fight not for kingship or dominion, but for equality between the people’s of Italy and the Trojans, yet he ends the war by mercilessly slaying his enemy Turnus.

This is the ultimate ambivalence of Aeneas’s quest: it is the one thing he does without divine guidance. Is this murder a failure, the Aeneid asks, brutal revenge replacing idealism, or is it an ultimate acceptance of personal responsibility, a recognition that in order to complete his quest he must commit necessary crimes?

title: "What a Loser That Guy Was": Norm Macdonald's Humorous Critique of the Romantic/ Warrior Narrative
summary: Illness narratives are stories that focus on, or are inspired by, the sometimes life-altering experience of illness. Most narrative constructions of these illness experiences are built upon one of three broad narrative "skeletons." One skeletal subform, the romantic/warrior narrative, is critiqued by comedian Norm Macdonald in a humorous anecdote that mocks the expectation that cancer patients must wage an epic and heroic battle against their pernicious cancer to have a chance to survive. Macdonald explicates that such a mentality produces heroes and villains, winners and losers, and places additional burden on cancer patients. In this analysis, I argue that Macdonald's effective use of humor and fulfillment of the five functions of health-related narration enable his story to gain narrative rationality and serve as effective rhetorical tools in encouraging the audience to accept the narrator's critique of the romantic/war-rior subform.

title: Arps, Creese, Cohen, and Foley 2017: Debate on Tall Tree, Nest of the Wind
summary: Reviews of Tall tree, nest of the wind (Arps 2016) by Helen Creese, Matthew Cohen, and Kathy Foley, followed by a response from the author (from BKI 173)

title: Ethno-religious heritage in Singapore and the Quest [= "Dewa Ruci" as a modern Malay shadowplay in 2012]
Mental Health, Crime, Sport, Community, and Island Life: The Post-Retirement Struggles of a Fiji Soccer Hero
summary: This article explores the soccer career of the ex-Fiji national-team player, Henry Dyer, and his post-retirement struggles. He experiences ‘fragmentation’ because of two ‘epiphanies’ (traumatic life-events)—his failure to get an elite coaching job after retirement and failure to secure an overseas playing-contract. After a period of fragmentation, when he cut all ties with the sport, he has reinvented himself as a caring person who, through the social and support club, Nadi Legends Club, visits ex-players going through illness. We also use Henry’s story as a gateway to explore (1) race and class aspects; and (2) masculinity issues. We look at the case through the theoretical lenses of symbolic interactionism and Foucault on power.
